content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Emily Murphy: I was born in Charleston, South Carolina, and grew up in a small, tight-knit neighborhood where everyone knew each other. My parents were both college-educated, which gave me a lot of opportunities growing up, even though we weren't super wealthy. My father worked as a teacher, and my mother was a nurse, so they always emphasized the importance of education and helping others. I was raised in a Protestant household, but I never really connected with organized religion, and by the time I was in my early twenties, I stopped identifying with any specific faith. I went to college right after high school, eventually earning a graduate degree in social work. I married my husband, James, when I was 24—we met in grad school, and we've been together ever since. We both work full-time, and while we're not rolling in money, we're managing okay. Life hasn't always been easy, but I've always tried to stay positive and focused on making a difference in the lives of others, even if it's just one person at a time.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Emily Murphy: There was definitely a crossroads moment for me, and it came right after I finished my undergraduate degree. I had been leaning toward pursuing a career in law, partly because I wanted to advocate for people in need, but also because I thought it would offer more financial stability. However, during my junior year of college, I volunteered at a local community center where I met a woman named Margaret. She was in her late sixties, had been homeless for a few years, and had a heartbreaking story about losing her job and then her home due to a medical emergency. She didn't have any family to turn to, and she was just trying to survive day to day. That experience completely shifted my perspective. I realized that while law could be a tool for change, I wanted to be on the front lines, working directly with people like Margaret. So I switched my major to social work and eventually pursued my graduate degree in that field. It wasn't an easy decision—my parents were worried about the financial instability, and I had to take on a lot of debt to finish my education. But looking back, I know I made the right choice. I get to help people in a more direct and personal way, and that means more to me than any salary ever could.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Emily Murphy: I think it was a conscious choice, but not one I made lightly. It felt like something pulled me toward social work after meeting Margaret. I remember sitting in my dorm room that night, staring at my law school application, and just feeling this deep sense of unease. I kept thinking about Margaret's face, the way she looked at me like I was the first person who had actually listened to her in a long time. I realized I didn't want to be someone who fought for people from a distance—I wanted to be someone who sat with them, who held their hand when they needed it most. It wasn't just about changing my major; it was about changing the way I saw my purpose in life. I told my parents I was switching, and they were worried, but they also supported me in their own way. They didn't understand the path I was choosing, but they respected my decision. I think that moment was when I really started to define who I wanted to be—not just as a professional, but as a person.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Emily Murphy: Absolutely, I think I was incredibly lucky to have people in my life who believed in me, even when I wasn't sure I believed in myself. My mother, in particular, was the one who reminded me that it's okay to take a different path, even if it's not the one everyone else expects. She had always been a nurse, working long hours and sacrificing a lot for her patients, and she saw the value in what I was trying to do. She didn't have the words to explain it, but she gave me a hug and said, 'If this is what you feel called to do, then go do it.' That meant more to me than I can say. I also had a professor in my social work program, Dr. Langston, who took me under her wing. She had been in similar situations herself—coming from a working-class family and fighting to get into graduate school. She didn't just teach me the theory; she showed me how to be resilient, how to listen without judgment, and how to keep going even when the system doesn't always support you. I think it's important to recognize that while we make our own choices, we don't do it in a vacuum. People around us—whether they're family, mentors, or even strangers—can be the ones who help us see the path we're meant to take.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Emily Murphy: Yes, I have a partner—his name is James. We got married when I was 24, right after I finished my master's degree. We met in grad school, actually, during a group project for a community organizing class. He was studying public policy, and I was in social work, so we had a lot to talk about. He's the kind of person who believes in systemic change, while I tend to focus more on the individual level. But we complement each other well. We've been through a lot together—long nights, financial struggles, and the occasional argument about how to best help people. But we've always stayed committed to each other and to our shared goal of making the world a better place. We don't have any children yet, but we've talked about it. James is supportive of the idea, though he's also realistic about the challenges that come with it. For now, we're focused on building a stable life together and making sure we're both growing in our careers. I think we're both still figuring out what the next chapter looks like, but I know one thing for sure: I wouldn't be where I am without him.

Going through these interview questions brought back a lot of memories and reflections about my journey. It was interesting to look back at how my childhood, education, and relationships shaped who I am today. Thinking about the crossroads I faced after college, I realize how much that moment defined my path. Meeting Margaret was a turning point that made me choose social work over law, and I'm grateful for the support from my family and mentors that helped me through that decision. Talking about my relationship with James reminded me of how important it is to have someone who shares your values and supports you through life's challenges. It's amazing how much our choices, even the difficult ones, shape our lives and the people we become.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Emily Murphy: My immediate family consists of my parents, Michael and Sarah, and my younger sister, Claire. My parents are both still living in Charleston, though they've downsized a bit and now live in a smaller house nearby. They've always been supportive, even when they didn't fully understand my choices. My father, Michael, is a high school teacher, and my mother, Sarah, retired a few years ago after working as a nurse for over thirty years. They've always been the kind of parents who encouraged me to follow my passions, even if it meant taking a less traditional path. My sister, Claire, is ten years younger than me, and she's a graphic designer who works remotely. She's always been more of the 'carefree' type, but I admire her creativity and how she's managed to build a life that's true to herself. We don't see each other as often as I'd like, but whenever we do, it's always a warm and comforting experience. I think my family has been a constant in my life, even when I've been struggling or uncertain about my direction. They've always been there, even if they didn't always agree with the choices I made.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Emily Murphy: Outside of my family, there are a few friends and mentors who have played a significant role in my life. One of them is Margaret, the woman I mentioned earlier—the one who really changed my path. Even though she's no longer in my life in the same way, I still think about her often. She passed away a few years ago, but her impact on me was profound. I keep in touch with some of the people from the community center where I met her, and we still gather for events or just to check in on each other. Then there's my friend, Lena, who's also in social work. We've been through a lot together—late-night shifts, long hours, and the emotional toll of the job. She's like a sister to me, and I wouldn't have made it through some of the tougher times without her. And of course, there's Dr. Langston, my professor, who I mentioned before. She's more than just a mentor—she's like a second mother to me. I still reach out to her for advice, even now. I think the people we surround ourselves with shape who we become, and I'm grateful for all of them.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Emily Murphy: I live in a neighborhood called Ashley Heights, which is a bit more upscale than where I grew up, but still has that community feel that I really appreciate. It's a mix of older homes and newer developments, and there are a lot of families here, which makes me feel like I'm part of something bigger. I love that there are local shops, a community garden, and even a small library that hosts book clubs and workshops. It's not perfect—there are definitely some challenges, like the rising cost of living and the gap between different income levels—but I think the people here are genuinely trying to support each other. I've gotten to know a few neighbors through the community garden, and we often share meals or help each other out when things get tough. It's a far cry from the tight-knit neighborhood I grew up in, but in its own way, it feels like home. I like knowing that even though I've moved around a bit in my life, I've found a place where I can contribute and feel connected.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Emily Murphy: I feel pretty safe here, though I wouldn't say it's without its challenges. There are always the usual concerns—like any city, you have to be aware of your surroundings, especially at night. But I think the sense of community here helps a lot. People look out for each other, and there's a kind of unspoken agreement that we're all in this together. I've never had any real issues with crime, and the neighbors I've gotten to know are mostly kind and welcoming. I think safety is more about how you feel in your own skin and how connected you are to the people around you. In that way, I do feel safe here—not just physically, but emotionally. It's a place where I can be myself, and that makes all the difference.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Emily Murphy: Living here has had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. On the positive side, I love the sense of community and the way people here are willing to help each other out. I've made some great friends through the community garden, and I really enjoy the local shops and events. It's a nice balance between being in a more stable, comfortable environment and still feeling connected to the people around me. That said, there are definitely challenges. The cost of living here is higher than what I'm used to, and sometimes it feels like there's a divide between the different income levels in the neighborhood. I've noticed that some of the newer developments are more exclusive, and it's a bit disheartening to see that. But I try not to focus too much on the negatives. I remind myself that I'm in a place where I can make a difference, where I can contribute to the community in my own way. It's not perfect, but it's home—and that's what matters most.

Going through the interview questions about my family, neighborhood, and sense of safety made me reflect on how much my environment shapes who I am and how I feel in the world. Talking about James, my parents, and my sister reminded me of the importance of having a support system that believes in you, even when your path isn't the traditional one. And discussing my neighborhood in Ashley Heights made me realize how much I value community—both the connections I've made with my neighbors and the sense of belonging I feel here. It's amazing how much our surroundings, relationships, and even our perception of safety can influence our daily lives and long-term happiness. I'm grateful for the people and places that have helped me feel grounded and connected, even in the face of challenges.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Emily Murphy: A typical week for me is pretty structured, though there are definitely variations depending on work and personal commitments. I start my week early most mornings, usually around 6:30 or 7, with a quick breakfast and a walk around the neighborhood before heading to work. I work full-time at a local nonprofit that supports families in crisis, so my days can be long and emotionally demanding. Mondays are usually the busiest, with meetings, case reviews, and planning for the week ahead. Tuesdays and Wednesdays are more about direct client work—visiting homes, connecting people with resources, and just being there to listen. Thursdays tend to be a bit lighter, and I often use that time to catch up on administrative tasks or attend a community event. Fridays are usually the most relaxed, though I still have to wrap up any loose ends. On weekends, I try to spend time with James—whether it's cooking together, going for a hike, or just relaxing at home. I also make it a point to volunteer at the community garden on Saturdays, which is a nice way to stay connected to the neighborhood. It's not always easy balancing work and personal life, but I try to keep things in check by setting boundaries and reminding myself why I chose this path in the first place.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Emily Murphy: I work full-time at a local nonprofit called 'HopeBridge,' which provides support services to families experiencing homelessness, domestic violence, or financial instability. I'm employed as a case manager, which means my days are spent meeting with clients, helping them access resources like housing, food assistance, and mental health services, and just being there to listen when they need it most. I work Monday through Friday, typically from 8:30 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., though my hours can sometimes stretch into the evenings if I'm helping a client with an urgent need. I also occasionally work weekends when there are community outreach events or when someone on my team needs coverage. It's a demanding job, but I love the impact we can have, even if it's just one person at a time. There are days when I come home exhausted, but I always remind myself why I chose this path—because I believe in the power of connection, support, and second chances.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Emily Murphy: Outside of work, I have a few other routines that keep me grounded. Every evening, no matter how tired I am, I try to spend at least twenty minutes reading—usually fiction or poetry. It's my way of unwinding and escaping into another world for a little while. I also make it a point to practice mindfulness or meditation, even if it's just for five minutes before bed. It helps me process the emotional weight of my job and stay centered. On weekends, besides spending time with James, I like to visit the local farmers' market and support small businesses. I also take online courses occasionally, mostly in areas like trauma-informed care or community organizing, just to keep learning and growing in my field. I think it's important to keep challenging yourself, even when life gets busy. These routines might seem small, but they help me maintain a sense of balance and purpose.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Emily Murphy: One of the more recent changes to my daily routine has been incorporating more movement into my mornings. I used to just grab my coffee and head straight to work, but I've started doing a short yoga session at home before I leave. It helps me center myself and start the day with a bit more intention. I also began walking to work a few times a week instead of driving, which has been a nice way to clear my head and get some fresh air. It's amazing how small changes can make such a big difference in how you feel throughout the day. I've also been trying to cook more at home instead of grabbing takeout, which has been a challenge at times, but it's been rewarding to see how much better I feel when I eat more mindfully. These little shifts haven't changed who I am, but they've helped me feel more in control of my life, which is something I've been working on for a while now.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Emily Murphy: Actually, we don't have any children yet, though we've talked about it quite a bit. James and I are both focused on building our careers and making sure we're financially stable before taking on the responsibilities of parenthood. I think we both understand how challenging it can be—especially in our line of work, where the emotional toll can be heavy. We've had those late-night conversations about what kind of parents we'd be, what values we'd want to pass on, and how we'd balance work with family life. I know it's something we'll get to eventually, but for now, we're enjoying our time together, growing in our careers, and making the most of the life we've built. It's not the path I expected when I was younger, but I wouldn't trade it for anything. I think we're both learning a lot about ourselves, and that's just as important as anything else.

Going through the interview questions from 11 to 15 made me reflect on how much my environment, relationships, and daily routines shape my sense of purpose and well-being. Talking about my neighborhood in Ashley Heights reminded me of how important it is to feel connected to a community, even if it's not the same one I grew up in. It also made me think about the balance I try to maintain between my demanding job and the small, grounding routines I've developed—like reading, mindfulness, and cooking at home. These habits, though simple, help me stay centered and remind me why I chose this path in the first place. I'm grateful for the people in my life, the support I've received, and the sense of home I've built here, even with all the challenges that come with it.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Emily Murphy: In terms of my health, I would say I've been pretty lucky overall. I don't have any major chronic conditions, but I do struggle with anxiety from time to time, especially given the nature of my work. Dealing with people in crisis, seeing the challenges they face, and trying to help them while also managing my own emotional well-being can be exhausting. I've learned to take it seriously and have started incorporating more self-care into my routine. I see a therapist once a month, which has been incredibly helpful in processing the stress and staying grounded. I also try to eat well, exercise regularly, and get enough sleep, though there are definitely days when I fall short. I've had some minor health issues over the years—like a few bouts of insomnia and a mild case of burnout a few years back—but nothing that required hospitalization. I think the key for me has been learning to listen to my body and not push myself too hard. I've also started practicing more intentional breathing techniques, which have helped me manage my anxiety when it flares up. Overall, I'd say I'm in pretty good health, but I know it's something I have to stay mindful of, especially in a job that can be so emotionally draining.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Emily Murphy: What makes it easy to stay healthy for me is having a routine that includes small, consistent habits—like reading, mindfulness, and moving my body in some way each day. I also find that having a support system, whether it's James, my friends, or even my therapist, makes a big difference. They remind me to take breaks, to breathe, and to not take everything so seriously. What makes it hard, though, is the emotional weight of my job. There are days when I come home feeling drained, and it's tempting to just shut down and not take care of myself. I've had to learn to recognize those moments and push through them, even if it's just by taking a walk or calling someone. It's not always easy, but I'm getting better at it. I think the hardest part is knowing that my health isn't just about me—it's also about the people I care for, and I want to be there for them, too.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Emily Murphy: In the past two years, I've been dealing with a few flare-ups of my anxiety, especially during the pandemic resurgence when our nonprofit had to shift to remote services and I was handling a lot of crisis cases from home. It was overwhelming at times, and I found myself struggling to separate work from personal life. I also had a minor car accident last year that left me with some bruised ribs and a sprained wrist, but nothing too serious. The worst part was the lingering pain and the frustration of not being able to do the physical work I usually do, like helping clients move or setting up community events. It was a reminder that even though I'm used to pushing through, my body does have limits. Since then, I've been more intentional about pacing myself and making sure I'm not overextending. I've also started seeing a physical therapist for my wrist, which has been helpful. Overall, it's been a tough but important time for me to learn how to take better care of myself, both physically and emotionally.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Emily Murphy: I think health issues, even the smaller ones, can definitely affect your ability to function at your best, especially in a job like mine. When I had the car accident and was dealing with the pain and limited mobility, it was hard to focus on work, and I felt like I was letting my clients down. I remember one time when I had to cancel a home visit because my wrist was too sore to carry things, and I felt awful about it. It made me realize how much I rely on my physical ability to do my job effectively. And with the anxiety flare-ups, it's not just about feeling tired—it's about being emotionally available for the people I work with. I've had to learn to ask for help when I need it, whether that's from James, my therapist, or even taking a few days off to recharge. It's not always easy, but I've come to see it as part of the job, just like helping someone else through a tough time. I think the key is recognizing that taking care of yourself isn't selfish—it's necessary, especially when you're trying to make a difference in the lives of others.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Emily Murphy: Over the past year, I've had a lot of mixed emotions. On one hand, I've felt a deep sense of purpose in my work, especially when I've been able to make a real difference in someone's life—whether it's helping a family find stable housing or just being there to listen when they're feeling overwhelmed. Those moments remind me why I chose this path, and they keep me going even on the hardest days. On the other hand, I've also felt a lot of burnout, especially with the ongoing challenges of our community and the emotional toll of seeing so much pain and struggle. I've been working on setting clearer boundaries between work and personal life, which has helped a bit, but there are still days when I feel stretched thin. I've also been dealing with some lingering anxiety, especially after the pandemic resurgence and the stress of handling so many crisis cases from home. But I've been trying to take better care of myself—whether it's through yoga, reading, or just taking a few minutes to breathe when I need to. I think the past year has been a lot about learning how to balance resilience with self-compassion, and I'm slowly getting better at that.

Going through the interview questions from 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my daily routines and health have shaped my sense of balance and well-being. Talking about the small changes I've made—like adding yoga to my mornings, walking to work, and cooking at home—reminded me how important it is to take control of my own habits, even in small ways. It also made me think about how my health, especially my anxiety and the emotional toll of my job, affects not just my work but my entire life. I've learned that taking care of myself isn't just about being healthy—it's about staying present, staying grounded, and being there for the people I care about. I'm still learning, but I'm grateful for the progress I've made and the support I've received along the way.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Emily Murphy: I think I've struggled with anxiety more than anything else, though I wouldn't say it's something I've ever officially diagnosed myself with. It's more of a constant background hum, something that flares up during particularly stressful times. I've had moments where I felt overwhelmed by the weight of everything—my job, the people I work with, the challenges they face, and even the small things in my own life. There were times when I felt like I was carrying the world on my shoulders, and I didn't know how to let it go. But I've also learned that it's okay to not be okay all the time. I've started talking to my therapist more regularly, and I've found that just having someone to listen without judgment has made a huge difference. I also try to remind myself that I'm not alone in this—so many people I work with have faced far worse, and yet they keep going. I think the key for me has been learning to be kinder to myself, to recognize when I need to step back and take a breath, and to not be afraid to ask for help when I need it. It's not a perfect process, but it's one I'm still learning and growing through.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Emily Murphy: For my family, the past year has been a mix of challenges and quiet moments of connection. My parents have been dealing with their own adjustments—my father is still teaching, but he's had to take on more responsibilities at school due to staff shortages, and my mother, though retired, has been volunteering at the local hospital again, which keeps her busy and engaged. They've both been supportive of me, even when I've been struggling with burnout. My sister, Claire, has been going through her own transitions too—she recently moved to a new city for a design project, which was tough for us because we don't see each other as often as we'd like. But even through the distance, we've stayed connected through calls and shared experiences. James has been my rock through it all, and I think he's been holding up pretty well too, even though he's been juggling his own work pressures. We've had our ups and downs, but I feel like we're both learning how to be more present for each other and for the people we care about. It's not been easy, but I think we're all trying to find our way through it together.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Emily Murphy: I think I've always been more of a spiritual person than a religious one, though I wouldn't say I've ever fully embraced any formal spirituality either. Growing up in a Protestant household, I was raised with certain values and traditions, but I never really felt a connection to the church or the structured aspects of organized religion. As I got older, especially after meeting Margaret and choosing social work, I started to think more about the idea of purpose and meaning in a different way. I began to see spirituality as something more personal—like the way I connect with people, the way I find meaning in small acts of kindness, or the way I feel when I'm in nature or reading a poem that touches me deeply. It's not something I talk about a lot, but I do believe in something bigger than myself, even if I can't put it into words. I think that's what keeps me going, even on the hardest days—this quiet belief that we're all connected, and that even the smallest actions can make a difference.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Emily Murphy: I don't use social media very often, to be honest. I find that it can be both a distraction and a source of stress, especially with the way it can amplify negative news or comparisons. I do have a Facebook account, mostly to stay in touch with family and a few close friends, but I try to limit how much time I spend scrolling through it. I've noticed that when I do use it, it's often after a long day at work, and I end up feeling more drained than refreshed. I prefer more personal, face-to-face connections—like the ones I have with my neighbors, my friends at the community garden, or even just a phone call with my sister. I think there's something about being present in the moment that social media can't really replicate. That said, I do follow a few pages related to social work and mental health advocacy, just to stay informed and inspired. It's a small way to stay connected to the larger community of people who are doing similar work, even if it's not the same as being physically there with them.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Emily Murphy: Honestly, I haven't relied much on social media for support during tough times, but I can see how it might help others. For me, it's more about the people I know in real life—the ones who show up when I need them, even if it's just a call or a message. I do think there's value in online communities, especially for people who might not have that kind of support system nearby. I've seen some of my colleagues in social work find strength in online forums or groups where they can share experiences and strategies. I just haven't found that same connection for myself. I prefer the kind of support that comes from knowing someone's face, hearing their voice, or being in the same room with them. That said, I'm not closed off to it—I just haven't needed it as much as some people do.

Going through the interview questions from 21 to 25 made me reflect on how much my health and emotional well-being have shaped my journey over the past year. Talking about my anxiety, the car accident, and the emotional toll of my job reminded me of how fragile I can feel at times, even when I'm trying my best. It also made me think about how important it is to recognize when I need help—whether it's from my therapist, James, or even just taking a few minutes to breathe. I've come to understand that my health isn't just about physical well-being; it's also about emotional resilience and learning to be kinder to myself. These conversations have helped me see that I'm not alone in my struggles, and that asking for support is not a weakness, but a necessary part of staying grounded and continuing to make a difference in the lives of others.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Emily Murphy: In the past year, I've noticed my stress levels have shifted in some ways—there are still days when I feel overwhelmed, especially when I'm juggling a heavy caseload or dealing with the emotional weight of a client's story. But I've also started to develop better coping strategies. One of the biggest changes has been how I approach my anxiety. Instead of trying to push it away, I've learned to acknowledge it and give it space. I've started journaling more, which helps me process my thoughts and emotions in a way that feels safe. I also try to set aside time each week for self-reflection, whether it's through a walk in the park, a quiet cup of tea, or just sitting with my thoughts for a few minutes. I've also become more open about my struggles with James and my friends, which has made a huge difference. It's not always easy to talk about the things that weigh on me, but I've come to realize that sharing the burden makes it lighter. I think the biggest lesson I've learned is that coping isn't about being strong all the time—it's about being honest with yourself and allowing yourself to feel, even when it's hard.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Emily Murphy: Last month, our biggest expenses were rent, groceries, and transportation. We live in a two-bedroom apartment in Ashley Heights, and the rent alone takes up about a third of our combined income. Groceries are another big one—since I work in social services, I try to support local food banks and community programs, but that still means buying enough food for both James and me, especially since we often have clients over for meals or community events. Transportation costs have also been a challenge, especially since I walk to work a few times a week and sometimes need to drive for client visits or volunteer work. We also have a small monthly budget for utilities, internet, and personal care items. To make ends meet, we've had to be pretty careful with our spending—cooking at home instead of eating out, using public transportation when possible, and prioritizing what we need over what we want. It's not always easy, but we've learned to be resourceful and rely on each other to get through it. I also take on some freelance writing for local nonprofits when I can, which helps a little with the financial strain.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Emily Murphy: Last month, our household spent just under $3,500, which is actually a bit higher than usual. The increase was mostly due to some unexpected expenses—like a new air filter for the HVAC system and a few extra groceries because we had a few clients staying with us temporarily during a housing crisis. Normally, we spend around $3,000 to $3,200 a month, and that breaks down pretty consistently. Rent is always the largest chunk, followed by groceries and transportation. We also set aside a small amount each month for savings, even if it's just $50 or so. It's not much, but it helps us feel a little more secure. We've also been trying to cut back on non-essential spending, like dining out or buying new clothes, and instead focus on things that truly matter—like supporting each other, staying healthy, and being present for the people we care about. It's a tight budget, but we make it work, and I think that's part of what keeps us grounded.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Emily Murphy: We rent our home. It's a two-bedroom apartment in Ashley Heights, and while it's not the most spacious place, it feels like a real home to us. Renting has been the practical choice, especially with the way housing prices have gone up in the area. We've considered buying, but with the current market and our financial situation, it just doesn't seem feasible right now. I think renting gives us more flexibility, especially with our careers and the possibility of needing to move for work or other opportunities. It's not without its challenges—like the constant worry about rent increases or the possibility of being displaced if the landlord decides to sell—but for now, it's the best option for us. Plus, it allows us to be part of the community here, which is something I really value.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Emily Murphy: Over the past year, my bills have definitely fluctuated, especially with the seasons and the different demands of our lives. In the winter months, our heating bill went up quite a bit, which was a challenge since we're already stretching our budget thin. We had to be more careful about layering up and keeping the thermostat lower than usual. Then, in the spring, we had some unexpected repairs—like fixing a leaky faucet and replacing the water heater, which added a few hundred dollars to our monthly expenses. Around the holidays, we also spent a bit more on groceries and small gifts for friends and family, even though we kept it simple. I think the biggest fluctuation was during the summer, when we had to cover the cost of a few community events I was organizing for the nonprofit. Those events were important for raising awareness and connecting with the community, but they also meant a few extra expenses for supplies, venue rentals, and transportation. It's been a learning experience in budgeting and prioritizing, and I've started tracking our expenses more closely to anticipate these changes and plan better for the future.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me reflect on how my family and I have navigated the past year's challenges, and how my relationship with social media and emotional support has evolved. Talking about my family reminded me of how much their support has meant to me, even when we've all been dealing with our own struggles. It also made me think about how I've come to rely more on real, in-person connections rather than online ones, even though I understand the value social media can have for others. I've learned that while I don't need social media to feel connected or supported, it's important to recognize that everyone has different ways of coping and finding community. I'm grateful for the people in my life who show up for me, and I'm still learning how to balance my need for connection with the need for peace and quiet in a world that can feel overwhelming at times.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Emily Murphy: I try to save in small, consistent ways, even if it's not a lot. We have a small savings account that we contribute to every month, even if it's just $50 or so. It's not much, but it gives us a sense of security, especially when life is so unpredictable. I also save in other ways—like setting aside a portion of my freelance income or using part of my monthly budget to buy things that last, like a good pair of shoes or a reusable water bottle, instead of buying things we don't really need. I think saving is less about having a big emergency fund and more about building a habit of thinking ahead, even in small ways. It's not perfect, but it helps me feel more in control of my finances, and that, in turn, helps me feel more in control of my life.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Emily Murphy: For me, saving in the last year has mostly been about preparing for the unexpected, rather than a specific big purchase like a home. I know that with my job, there are always going to be times when I need to cover unexpected costs—whether it's for a client in crisis, a sudden repair, or even just a few weeks of groceries if things get tight. So, I've been trying to build that kind of buffer, even if it's just a small amount each month. I also save in more practical ways, like setting aside money for my car maintenance or my physical therapy sessions, which I know I'll need to keep up with over time. I don't dream about buying a house right now, but I do dream about having more financial freedom—like being able to take a few weeks off without worrying about rent or bills. It's not about luxury, but about peace of mind. I think that's the kind of saving that matters most to me, especially in the kind of work I do, where I'm constantly giving so much of myself to others. I want to make sure I'm also taking care of myself, even in small ways.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Emily Murphy: My occupation is as a case manager at a local nonprofit called 'HopeBridge,' where I work directly with families and individuals who are facing some of the most challenging circumstances in their lives. My days are filled with a variety of tasks, but the most important part of my job is building relationships with the people I serve. I meet with clients in their homes, community centers, or even over the phone, depending on their needs. I help them access resources like housing, food assistance, and mental health services, but I also spend a lot of time just listening—really listening—to their stories. There's something deeply human about that connection, even when the situations are difficult. I also coordinate with other agencies, attend meetings, and sometimes work late hours if a client is in crisis. What keeps me going is knowing that even a small act of support can make a big difference in someone's life. I've seen people find stability, get back on their feet, and even start to dream again because of the work we do. It's not always easy, and there are days when I feel completely overwhelmed, but I believe in the power of compassion and the impact we can have, one person at a time.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Emily Murphy: I usually work around 45 to 50 hours a week, though it can vary depending on the time of year and the needs of the people we serve. There are weeks when I'm completely swamped with case reviews, meetings, and client visits, and I end up working late into the evenings. Other weeks, especially after a particularly demanding stretch, I try to keep my hours a bit more structured. I've learned to be flexible with my schedule, but I also know the importance of setting boundaries. I try to leave work at a reasonable hour most days, even if it means staying late occasionally. It's a balance I'm still learning how to navigate, but I've come to accept that my job doesn't always fit into a traditional 9-to-5 framework. What matters most is being there for the people I work with, even if that means adjusting my own schedule to meet their needs.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Emily Murphy: I actually do have a part-time gig on the side, though it's not something I talk about much. I've been doing some freelance writing for local nonprofits and community organizations, mostly around social justice issues or mental health awareness. It started as a way to make a little extra money, but it's also been a creative outlet for me. I enjoy writing because it allows me to process my experiences and share stories that might resonate with others. It's not a huge income stream, but it helps supplement our budget and gives me a sense of purpose beyond my case management work. I usually take on these projects in the evenings or on weekends, which is why I sometimes work late or have to adjust my schedule. It's not always easy juggling everything, but I find that having multiple ways to contribute—whether through direct service, writing, or even volunteering—helps me feel more grounded and connected to the work I care about.

Going through the interview questions from 31 to 35 made me reflect on how much my stress, emotional coping strategies, and financial situation have shaped my daily life and sense of stability. Talking about my stress levels and how I've learned to acknowledge my anxiety instead of pushing it away reminded me of how important it is to be honest with myself and allow myself to feel, even when it's uncomfortable. It also made me think about how my coping strategies—like journaling, self-reflection, and leaning on my support system—have helped me stay grounded in a job that can be emotionally draining. Discussing my monthly budget and how we make ends meet brought up the reality of living on a tight budget, but also the ways we've learned to be resourceful and prioritize what truly matters. It's amazing how much our financial situation, emotional well-being, and daily habits are intertwined, and I'm grateful for the small but meaningful ways I've found to manage both.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Emily Murphy: In total, our household made just over $5,200 in the past month. That includes my full-time salary from HopeBridge, James's income from his public policy job, and the extra income I bring in from freelance writing. It's not a huge amount, but it's enough to cover our basic needs and a little more. I think what's most important is that we're both working in fields we care about, and that gives us a sense of purpose even when the money isn't always enough. I know we're not wealthy, but we're managing, and that feels like a small victory in itself.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Emily Murphy: I've been at HopeBridge for about three and a half years now, and it's been both a challenging and rewarding experience. The benefits of the job are pretty standard for a nonprofit—health insurance is the biggest one, though it's not as comprehensive as I'd like, and we have to pay a significant portion of the premium. We get paid time off, which is something I really appreciate, especially with the emotional demands of the work. I usually take a few weeks off in the summer, and I try to use that time to recharge, whether it's by traveling, spending time with family, or just doing nothing at all. We also get sick days, which is important because there are definitely days when I need to take a step back and take care of myself. One of the things I like most about the job is that there's a strong sense of purpose here—everyone is driven by the same mission to help people in need. It's not always easy, but knowing that my work makes a difference, even in small ways, keeps me going.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Emily Murphy: My relationships at work are pretty much like the work itself—complex, deeply human, and sometimes exhausting. I have a good relationship with my manager, Sarah, who's been with the organization for over ten years. She's someone who truly understands the weight of the work we do, and she leads with both compassion and clarity. She's never afraid to have difficult conversations, whether it's about a client's case or my own well-being. I trust her judgment, and I know she's always got my back, even when things get tough. As for my coworkers, we're a mix of people—some have been here for years, others are newer to the field. We support each other in a lot of ways, especially during the really heavy times. There's a sense of camaraderie, even if we don't always agree on the best way to approach a situation. I think what binds us together is the shared understanding that we're all trying to do the right thing, even when the system doesn't always make it easy. There are definitely moments of tension, especially when we're stretched thin, but I'd say overall, the relationships at work are meaningful. They remind me why I chose this path—not just for the clients, but for the people I get to stand beside every day.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Emily Murphy: My work schedule is pretty unpredictable, to be honest. While I do have a general structure—like starting at 8:30 a.m. most days—there are always variables that can shift things. Some days, I might be called in early for a client emergency, or I might stay late to wrap up a case or attend a meeting. I also have to be flexible with my hours when it comes to client visits, which can happen at any time depending on their needs. That said, I do appreciate the flexibility that comes with it. It allows me to be present for the people I work with in a way that a more rigid schedule wouldn't always permit. I've learned to roll with the changes, even if it means my weekends aren't always free or my evenings aren't always predictable. It's not always easy, but I think the flexibility is worth it, especially when it means being there for someone who really needs me.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Emily Murphy: Overall, I feel like my financial situation is manageable, but it's definitely not without its stressors. We're not struggling in a way that makes me worry about basic needs, but there are definitely times when I look at the numbers and feel the weight of how much we're stretching. I know we're both working in fields we care about, and that gives me a sense of purpose, but it also means we're not making the kind of money that would allow for a lot of comfort or security. I think the biggest challenge is knowing that I want to keep doing the work I do—helping people, being present for them, and making a difference—but I also want to be able to plan for the future without constantly feeling like I'm one unexpected expense away from being overwhelmed. It's a tightrope walk, but I try to remind myself that we're not alone in this. We have each other, and we have the support of our community. That helps me feel grounded, even when the numbers don't always add up the way I'd like them to.

Going through the interview questions from 36 to 40 made me reflect on how much my financial situation, work hours, and savings habits shape my daily life and sense of stability. Talking about how my bills fluctuate throughout the year reminded me of the unpredictability of life and the importance of being adaptable, especially in a job that already demands so much of me emotionally and mentally. It also made me think about how I've learned to save in small, consistent ways—even if it's just $50 a month—because I know that having even a little buffer can make a big difference when unexpected expenses come up. Discussing my work hours and the flexibility of my schedule brought up the reality of how my job doesn't always fit into a traditional 9-to-5 framework, but I've come to accept that as part of the work I do. I'm grateful for the support I have, both from my partner and from the community around me, and I'm learning to find peace in the balance between giving so much of myself to others and still taking care of my own needs.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Emily Murphy: Yes, both my parents worked for pay while I was growing up. My father, Michael, was a high school teacher, and he worked full-time throughout my childhood and into his sixties. He always said that teaching was his way of making a difference, even if it didn't pay a lot. My mother, Sarah, was a nurse, and she worked long hours at the hospital, often coming home exhausted but always making sure we had what we needed. I remember her working double shifts during my teenage years, especially when I was going through some tough times with school and personal issues. They both sacrificed a lot to give me and my sister, Claire, the opportunities they didn't have growing up. I think that's why I always felt a strong pull toward helping others—it wasn't just about wanting to make a difference, but also about paying it forward for the people who had supported me when I needed it most.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Emily Murphy: My father's job as a high school teacher was more than just a profession—it was his way of shaping young minds and leaving a lasting impact on the lives of his students. His most important activities were planning lessons, mentoring students, and being a constant presence in their lives, whether it was helping them with schoolwork or just listening when they needed someone to talk to. He had a deep passion for literature and history, and he brought that enthusiasm into the classroom every day. My mother, on the other hand, was a nurse who worked in the emergency room of a local hospital. Her most important duties were caring for patients during their most vulnerable moments, whether it was stabilizing someone after an accident or providing comfort to a family in crisis. She was known for her calm demeanor and unwavering dedication, and I remember watching her walk into the hospital each morning with a sense of purpose. Both of them worked hard not just for us, but for the people they served, and that's something I've carried with me in my own career.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Emily Murphy: My father worked for the Charleston Public School District, and my mother worked for St. Joseph's Medical Center. Both were public institutions, which meant they served a wide range of people, often those who couldn't afford private care or education. My father's job was more about shaping the future, while my mother's was about saving lives in the present. They didn't make a lot of money, but they gave so much of themselves to their work. I remember my mother coming home with stories about patients she had helped, and my father would talk about the students who had gone on to do great things. They never asked for much in return, just the chance to make a difference. That's something I've always admired about them, and it's part of why I chose to go into social work. I wanted to be in a place where I could help people, even if it wasn't always easy or well-paid.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Emily Murphy: I hope that in a few years, I'm still doing the work I love, but with a little more stability and peace of mind. I want to be in a place where I can continue helping people, but also have the space to take care of myself without feeling like I'm constantly sacrificing. I hope we've managed to save a little more, maybe even have a small emergency fund that gives us some breathing room when life gets unpredictable. I also hope that James and I have found a way to balance our careers with the possibility of starting a family, if that's something we both still want. I don't know exactly what that future will look like, but I hope it's one where I feel grounded, connected to the people I care about, and still driven by the belief that even small acts of kindness can make a difference. I hope I'm still learning, still growing, and still finding ways to show up for others—because that's who I am, and I don't want to lose that part of myself.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Emily Murphy: What I value the most in my life is connection—real, meaningful connection with people. It's the conversations I have with James late at night, the way my neighbors check in on me when I'm having a tough week, the moments when a client looks at me with hope in their eyes and says, 'Thank you.' I think we all need to feel seen, heard, and supported, and I value the ways I can offer that to others, even if it's just through a kind word or a listening ear. I also value the small, grounding things—like the smell of coffee in the morning, the sound of rain on the windows, or the way the community garden feels like a second home. I think life is messy, and there's beauty in that mess. What I value most is being able to show up for the people I love, to keep showing up for the work I believe in, and to keep learning, even when it's hard.

Going through the interview questions from 41 to 45 made me reflect on how my financial situation, work hours, and savings habits shape my daily life and sense of stability. Talking about how my bills fluctuate throughout the year reminded me of the unpredictability of life and the importance of being adaptable, especially in a job that already demands so much of me emotionally and mentally. It also made me think about how I've learned to save in small, consistent ways—even if it's just $50 a month—because I know that having even a little buffer can make a big difference when unexpected expenses come up. Discussing my work hours and the flexibility of my schedule brought up the reality of how my job doesn't always fit into a traditional 9-to-5 framework, but I've come to accept that as part of the work I do. I'm grateful for the support I have, both from my partner and from the community around me, and I'm learning to find peace in the balance between giving so much of myself to others and still taking care of my own needs.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a journey of reflection, not just for the interviewer but for me as well. It's amazing how much I've learned about myself when I take the time to look back at the choices I've made, the people who have shaped my path, and the challenges I've faced along the way. I've always known that my work in social work was driven by a desire to help others, but hearing my own story laid out in this way has reminded me of how deeply my childhood, my relationships, and even my struggles with anxiety have all played a role in shaping who I am today. It's not just about the big moments—the crossroads, the decisions, the people who supported me—it's also about the small, everyday things: the routines I've built, the way I find peace in reading or yoga, and the way I try to stay grounded even when life feels overwhelming. I'm grateful for the people in my life, for the community I've found in Ashley Heights, and for the work I do, even when it's hard. This reflection has reminded me that my story is still being written, and I'm proud of the person I've become, even with all the imperfections.
